Posts.Content: May 23, 2011 12:21PM BritValarie wrote: Hi Tina, I am so sorry you are going through this.  I know it must be torture!! But, nothing is certain until you have the pathology report back.   Just know that I am thinking and praying for a good outcome. B9 thoughts!! Take care, Valarie
Posts.Title: Overwhelmed Luebbsgurl suzanneinphoenix

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2011 10:50AM BritValarie wrote: Hi kbeyer30, I'm sorry no one has answered your post.  But, I've been where you are!  My maternal grandmother died of breast cancer at 47.  My mother died of BC when she was 38. I have had several issues/biopsies/surgeries and now have LCIS - Lobular Carcinoma In Situ, Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia and Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia.  All three are considered pre-cancerous or pre-cursors to breast cancer.  So, because of my family history and my issues I am scheduled for a propholactic double mastectomy on December 7th.  I am 49. Hopefully, at the breast care clinic they will advise you to get genetic testing.  I am assuming you are much younger than me :)  If so, ask about getting annual MRI's and of course, mammograms. I am so sorry for the loss of your mother! Take care, Valarie

But, it's B9!!  I am so glad your waiting is over! {{{{{{HUGS}}}}}}} Valarie

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 03:30PM BritValarie wrote: njmae, You attitude on your diagnosis is awesome!!  I am so happy that it was caught very early.  With a positive attitude like yours, you know you can do the same thing to BC as you did to melanoma! My best friend had stage 4 melanoma and was given 6 months to live, but she has such an incredible attitude to life, she fought with everything she had.  She is now NED (No Evidence of Disease). Hugs, Valarie
Posts.Title: Got the call at noon... njmae worriedwoman

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2011 02:06PM BritValarie wrote: DocBabs, Like carpdiem1965, I also used your case to make my decision to have BMX.  My mother died of BC at the age of 38.  My grandmother at 47.  I myself have been diagnosed with ADH, ALH and LCIS.  Everytime I go for screening, they find more calcs, or find that the calcs have increased.  In the last year, I've had 4 stereo biopsies and a surgical biopsy. My last MRI picked up lots of things that they labeled as "probably" benign.  I have dense breasts and have been told I have several cysts in both breasts. I don't want the stress anymore, or the chance that there is something in there they haven't detected, like you.  So, December 7th I am having BMX with imediate DIEP reconstruction. I know this route isn't for everyone, but I feel great about my decision.  I do not want to spend anymore of my time, and money on testing and biopsies... and the stress that goes along with it. Happy Thanksgiving, everyone! Valarie
Posts.Title: Six Months Rotation... sharkbait DocBabs

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 09:56AM BritValarie wrote: Carylc, I had  bilateral biopsies done Jan 14th.  I had 12 samples taken out of my right breast, and 6 taken out of my left.  I would say the worst part was laying face down on the table to an hour or so.  Other than that, doing both sides was not too bad at all. I don't think I would have liked having 2 seperate biopsies and waiting for 2 seperate results.  So, I can understand your concern. Good luck...and come back and update us.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy question CarylC CarylC

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2011 02:49PM BritValarie wrote: Hello Ladies, This thread is very interesting! I have a family history of breast cancer.  My maternal grandmother died of BC at 47, my mother died of BC at 38...and her sister, my aunt died at 41. I have had several biopsies and surgeries all resulting in a diagnosis of ADH, ALH and LCIS.  I tested negative for genetic testing.  Even so, the stress of going through this every 6 months was just too much.  I really did not want to take Tamoxifen, so I am scheduled for a PBM with immediate reconstruction on December 7th. I know this is a very personal decision, but for me I did not want to go on wasting time out of my life constantly worrying when something worse might show up.  I was 11 when my mother passed away.  One day when we we home alone, she showed me where she had her mastectomy.  Not to scare me, but to make me promise that I would do everything not to go through what she went through.  I guess I'm keeping that promise with the upcoming surgery. I have VERY cystic and dense breasts, so I feel a lot more comfortable doing this surgery Take care, Valarie

Posts.Content: May 24, 2011 03:39PM BritValarie wrote: Hi mammafax, Our stories sound very familiar!  My mother died of BC when she was 38.  Her mother, my grandmother died before I was born somewhere around 50.  My mother's sister, my aunt died of BC around the age of 42.  My father and a brother have passed away from Prostate Cancer. I have had 2 lumpectomies, and several biopsies.  In December my biopsies diagnosed epithial ductal hyperplasia. I am going to see a breast specialist next month to hopefully get some guidance on what to do from here.

Posts.Title: ALH farmerlucy Diane5

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 08:24AM - edited Feb 6, 2012 08:25AM by BritValarie I just want you to know that I was where you are a few short months ago. My mother passed when she was 38 from breast cancer, my grandmother in her late 40's and my moms sister at 41. I tested negative(undetermined) for BRCA 1 & 2. I have had several biopsies and 3 lumpectomies. In the last couple of years, pathology has come back with LCIS, ADH and ALH... all in the left breast. So, I opted for a PBMX with reconstruction (DIEP) on December 7th. I can't tell you the relief I feel, especially since I got the pathology report back. LCIS, ADH & ALH in left breast (according to my latest MRI it had all been removed when I had my lumpectomy. But, it also showed extensive ADH and ALH in the right breast. In all my screenings I have always been told the right breast was clear. SO, be vigilent and go with what you feel is right for you! Good luck, ladies....and let me know if you have any questions. I would be happy to give my email address, or cell number if you private message me. Take Care, Valarie
Posts.Title: ALH farmerlucy Diane5

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2011 02:37PM BritValarie wrote: Hi Kimmer1975 I had a Complex Cyst in December and the recommendation was a needle biopsy.  There is a "slight" chance of malignancy with these types of cysts.  Mine was totally benign but had lots of septations.  Take Care, Valarie
Posts.Title: Is it true? Kimmer1975 Kimmer1975

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 09:14AM BritValarie wrote: baileyjo... my story is almost identical to yours!  I found a mass/lump in my breast... didn't worry too much about it, then after a couple of weeks it was still there, so I went to see my GYN.  He ordered a diagnostic mammo and ultrasound.  The radiologist came to see me afterwards and said it looked like a cyst, but with stuff all around and inside it.  But, she was concerned because I also had calcifications in both breasts. Even though my mother died of BC at age 38, I have never really worried about it.  Well, the radiologist sent the report to my Dr's office and it took over a week to call me and schedule the MRI.  I have an appt for Wednesday.  The radiologist said that regardless of the MRI, she wants me to have a biopsy on both breasts for the calcifications.  However, my dr says lets wait and see what the MRI shows. Like you, I'm a pretty positive person and tend not to worry about things unless I have to....but, this time, I've been flip flopping.  So, I really understand what you mean.  You want to be positive because the Dr. says its "probably" nothing, but you can't help thinking, "what if". So hang in there and know we are here for you if you need to talk or vent. Hugs, Valarie

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 08:44AM BritValarie wrote: Hi Ladies, I am also getting bilateral biopies on both breasts for calcifications on the 14th.  I also have a Thick walled cyst in my left breast.  My mother died of BC when she was 38 years old, so I think they are just being cautious.  Both the calcification and cyst were rated Birads 4... which just means a biopsy is recommended to rule out anything suspicious. I know its so easy to freak out about it, its a natural reaction to the unknown.  I am just glad they are taking the steps to ensure me that everything is ok. So, I hope there's room in that boat for me :) Valarie
